electronics.name: Electric Drill
electronics.introduction: Electric drills are not as complicated as you may think. I wanted to know more about them to I took apart an old drill my brother for at a flea market.

iterations.title: Introduction
iterations.introduction: Recently my brother happened to find an old electric drill at a local flea market and I figured this would be a good project to learn more about how electric drills work. The drill is in decent shape but it is old. We tried it and it did not work, and initially we thought we would just scrap it for parts. Afterall, there is large eletric motor, a motor controller, and a battery and if even 1 of those works then the $5 invenestment my brother made was worth it. After some investigation, we noticed that the motor and motor controller are still fully operational, but the batteries are all done. When I saw the batteries are done, I mean 0 volts and visibly oxidized.

blurbs.title: Drill components
blurbs.text: The drill itself is as simple as a machine can get. It is also so old that I cannot find the exact model online, it is a 14.4v Bosch Brute drill. The image is the cross section of the drill with the parts annotated. The first component is the Chuck, which is used to fasten the drill bits to the motor. The second component is the Gearbox, basically including gears that allow for more torque or more speed controlled by the switch at the top. Third, the Electric Motor, a device that converts electricity into mechanical rotation. The fourth component is a Motor Controller, which allows the user to set different speeds for the motor buy allowing a higher or lower voltage into the motor. Note, a general rule of thumb is that a higher voltage will provide higher speed speed whereas more amperage will provide more torque. The motor controller is likely the most technical part of all of this but there are really just a couple of mosfets, switches, diodes, and a spring. And lastly, the Battery that powers the device, in this case they appear to be Nickelâ€“cadmium batteries.

images.name: electric_drill_annot
images.alt: An electric drill with the cover taken off and the parts annotated.

electronics.name: Dehumidifier
electronics.introduction: To make a dehumidifier you need a source of cold, since as air cools it drops moisture. One method of converting electricity into cold is using a Thermoelectric Cooler or Peltier Cooler. I happen to have a couple of TECs and old computer fans lying around and thought I might try making a small dehumidifier.

guides.name: Car OBD II
guides.introduction: Most modern cars use what is known as On-board diagnostic, abbreviated to OBD II. I did some research so I can do basic diagnostics on my car.

blurbs.title: Connecting to Bluetooth
blurbs.text:
Connect the OBD II scanner into the slot in your car, it's often near the driver's seat. I used Linux on my laptop to connect to the bluetooth device. The device will pair but does not connect so I had to connect a raw serial terminal to a bluetooth connection. All inputs are considered files and if you know where they are, /dev/ in Linux, you can open and read them like a file.
To connect to the raw serial use the command sudo rfcomm connect /dev/rfcomm0 MAC_ID 1 &. For more context, /dev/ is where input device files generally reside. This command creates a file to facilitate the communication, rfcomm is the bluetooth protocol

blurbs.title: Scanner software
blurbs.text: There are a couple of open source options to read the scanner output. I used a program that was based on pyOBD. The version of pyOBD I used had been reworked a little and it worked well. The documentation provided was straight forward and I followed it to get the program running. After the setup, use python3 pyobd.py to run the program. Another option is the python obd library for more finetuned control of the data.

guides.name: CUPS: Remote printer
guides.introduction: My dad got an old printer from a garage sale and though the printer is excellent it does not have wireless printing. The printer itself is of good quality and for a few dollars it was worth the money. Instead of trying to find some fancy printer, I decided to try to see if I can find a workaround for this. And since I like learning new things, especially related to tech, that is exactly what I did. I used CUPS to along with my Raspberry Pi 3B+ to turn the printer into a wireless printer!

blurbs.title: Description
blurbs.text:
1. Install CUPS using: https://www.raspberrypi.com/news/printing-at-home-from-your-raspberry-pi/
  2. To turn the Raspberrry Pi into a print server use: https://www.tomshardware.com/how-to/raspberry-pi-print-server
    • sudo cupsctl --remote-any
  3. Use cupsctl --remote-admin to allow for remote admin
  4. Find your printer driver online
    • Brothers printer drivers
    • In my case I have to find a driver for Brother HL-2040 series https://www.openprinting.org/printer/Brother/Brother-HL-2040

1. First check that you have a compatible graphics card. CUDA is specifically designed for NVIDIA GPUs.
    • Note, you can check if your GPU is compatible at https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-gpus
  2. Install the CUDA toolkit sudo apt install nvidia-cuda-toolkit
    • Documentation for CUDA: https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-compiler-driver-nvcc/index.html
  3. Check that the PCI bus is accessible using lspci | grep -i nvidia
    • Resource from http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/man8/lspci.8.html
    • If this does not work run sudo update-pciids
      • Resource from http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages//artful/man8/update-pciids.8.html
      • Then run the previous command again
  4. Check that the installation worked using nvcc --version
    • Additional CUDA documentation https://helpmanual.io/help/nvcc/
  5. Beginner tutorial at https://cuda-tutorial.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials/tutorial01/

blurbs.title: General
blurbs.text:
1. How to install Git https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/install-git
  2. How to create a PAT https://docs.github.com/en/githubauthenticating-to-github/keeping-your-account-and-data-secure/creating-a-personal-access-token
  3. How to cache a PAT https://docs.github.com/en/githubauthenticating-to-github/keeping-your-account-and-data-secure/creating-a-personal-access-token

blurbs.title: Steps
blurbs.text:
1. Generate a PAT and copy it
  2. Set your email and username
    • git config --global user.email yourEmail@github.com
    • git config --global user.name yourGitHubUserName
  3. Storing the credentials
    • For temporary storage git config --global credential.helper cache
    • For permanent storage git config --global credential.helper store
    • NOTE: remove --global to store the credentials in the specified repo
  4. Run git clone https://github.com/UserName/your.git
    • Enter your username
    • Enter your PAT
  5. From now on, every time you pull it should access the token automatically (or temporarily if you used cache)

1. Go to the windows store to install Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS, or a version that you like
  2. Then you have to enable the right Windows features
    1. You can press start and search: Turn Windows features on or off
    2. Then enable Windows Subsystems for Linux
    3. To enable this feature, you will need to restart your comtpuer
  3. For newer versions of WSL, enable the following: (source https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/5014)
    • Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux
    • VirtualMachinePlatform

plants.name: Sarracenia
plants.introduction: Sarracenia is a species of carivorous plants, also sometimes referred to as a Trumpet Pitcher Plant. These plants are quite unique in almost every aspect about them. I got my first Saraccenia from my grandmother in 2022. I now have two subspecies of the plant.

iterations.title: Sarracenias in general
iterations.introduction: Since these are two sub-species of each other they share a lot of common traits. The first fact I want to state is that these plants do not have moving parts that they use to catch their pray. And though you may think these plants are not going to survive they are excellent at what they do, catching insects. Everything from the shape to their taste and smell are desgined to make them merciless bug hunters. I have two sub-special Sarracenia Farnhamii and Sarracenia purpurea

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Background
blurbs.text:
These plants exist primarily in the North Americas. That's right, right here in our own homes! The environment these plants are adapted to live in bogs and wet grasslands. These environments are generally not well shaded due to larger plants' roots suffocating in the water which means near constant direct sunlight. Additionally, the water in the environment is usually nutrient poor. So, basically this plant has two of the three ingredients it needs to survive, the third being nutrients to grow.

Due the the lack of nutrients the plants adapted to catch insects. Additionally, these plants have gotten really good at absorbing any nutrients that land on them, so you are not actually allowed to touch them or risk chemical burns wherever you touched the plant. When I repot them I usually make sure to keep my hands wet to dilute anything that might be on my hands. It also helps to mist them with water.

With regards to climate, these plants live in the warmer parts of the North Americas but still experience a winter dormancy period. During the colder seasons, the leaves (the pitchers) will start to brown and die. Once the frost hits all the leaves will die and all that will be left are the roots. The roots, or rather the crown, survives the winter and starts growing more leaves, and sometmies flowers, in the spring time.

blurbs.title: Different traits: Environment
blurbs.text:
There are four main things that we need to match in terms of the environment: soil, water, light, and dormancy. The rest, bugs, will sort themselves out when the plants are outside, as mentioned they are great hunters.

For the soil I used one part peat moss and one part perlite. Peat moss is by itself has very little to no nutrients the plant can use while having amazing water retention due to the shredded sphagnum moss inside. Warning, sphagnum moss is horrible at absorbing water when it is already dry as aposed to humid or damp! However, by itself peat moss will compact and become hard so it needs something to give it structure. For that I have used perlite which makes the soil fluffy and not retain water well, or in other words provides drainage. The down side of this is that is not easy to work with and apparently toxic to breathe. There are a couple of alternatives I have been wanting to try like coconut husks.

In this case water will be classified as humidity in the air or in the soil. It is important to understand that moisture in the soil is different from mud. In wet highlands, the ground would be fibrious and fluffy meaning that roots have access to water but also to air. There are two things we do to simulate humidity. The first, is to put sphagnum moss on top of the soil to cover it. The moss itself holds moisture but as it covers the ground it helps the ground retain moisture as well. The second is that I like to have them stand in a deeper dish and a little bit of water. The bottom of the dish will have some aquarium gravel in it and the pot is less than 10% in the water, really not deep! This allows the soil to constantly absrobe moisture without the roots standing in water. The roots should never be submerged in water but should always have humidity around them.

images.name: sarracenia_roots
images.alt: The exposed root system of a sarracenia crown.

blurbs.text:
For the bottom dish of water, I have tried using distilled water, rain water, and well water. With distilled and rain water I have noticed that the water will turn a black or brown color and by the end of the year there were red little worms living in it. Not pleasant. With well water I usually have a lot of algea grow in, which does not harm the Sarracenia while also absorbing nutrients in the water. Algea and Sarracenias seem to have a symbiotic relationship in this case. The water will not be harmful to you or the plant, the water will not be smelly, and it is easy to clean with simple rinse and dollar-store strainer. I will note that I live in North America meaning that untreated well water is more or less exactly the water these plants are used to, so it makes sense to me that they grow well in it.

Light is an easy one if you can put the plants outside in the summer. They need a fair amount of sunlight, I have had them in places where they would get a good 12 hours of direct sunlight in 30 C weather and did not show a sign of stress. Slightly shaded light outside will also often do the trick. Remember, these plants live in the North Americas so the climate here is more or less perfect for them. The reason why I cannot grow them outdoors is that the winters where I am get much too cold. As they are dormant during the winter and the summers are warm are perfect where I live I do not keep them indoors much. I would imagine you would need strong lights.

Dormancy for these plants would happen around november, giving them until about march for dormancy. In this case dormancy means wait until the soil is just slightly moist, trim the leaves off, sprinkle sulfur on top of the soil/moss to avoid mold, and put them in a fridge. Since the plant is dormant, it will not grow or photosynthesize so it does not need its leaves but it also cannot be completely dry. The dormancy period lasts 3 to 4 months and after that the plants can be taken out again. Having the plants at about 3C in the fridge seems to be cold enough that it simulates winter for these plants, freezing them should be avoided and will likely kill them.

images.name: sarracenia_young
images.alt: A picture of a young Sarrcenia Farnhamii.

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Water and Fertilizer
blurbs.text:
These plants primarily get their nutrients from digesting insects as their environments generally does not offer nutrients otherwise. Distilled or rain water is often recommended, however I have had success with well water. Well water is clean and has some minerals it but does not seem to harm the plants even when directly watered. With that said, water that has chlorine or water that has been softened are generally not good for plants and will be deadly to these plants due to how well they have adapted to absorbing nutrients.

With regards to fertilizer, these plants generally do not need any. If they are indoors and are not particularly catching much, you can take a tiny bit of all purpose fertilizer, mix it into water and spray the plants with it. If the plants are catching bugs then this is generally not needed.

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Catching insects
blurbs.text:
They produce a nectar around the brim of the opening. This nectar is sweet, it is compared to the nectar found in flowers. The brim will have visible beads of nectar. I touched a bead once and it was really sticky and smelled sweet. I want to know what it tastes like but I also don't wanna share a meal with flies if I can help it. This nects is meant to attract insects to the opening of the pitcher, I have noticed that flies will crawl all over the plant and I suspect that the whole plant is sweet to alure insects. Once they insect notices the nectar they generally attempt to eat it without falling into the hole. The underside of the part of the leaf that covers the opening, has many little hairs that the insects cannot hold onto. This design makes the nectar uncomfortable for the flies to reach from the open end, wheres the underside of the leaf is not a place they can stand. Once they try, the tumble into the plant pitcher. Once the bug falls inside the pitcher, thye have great difficulty getting out which is for different reasons depending on which subspcies. However, the nectar around the brim and the little hairs are generally how these plants catch their prey. Additionally, flies are attracted to the smell of other dead flies so the plants only attracts more insects both with more leaves that provide a sweet aroma as well as the stench of decaying insects. Generally, I don't notice a smell because the plants are really good at absorbing the nutrients.

I read it somewhere, but I have also witnessed that spiders like to make webs on these plants as it attracts a lot of insects, often inevitably leading to the spider falling into the plant.

images.name: sarracenia_purpurea
images.alt: Sarracenia purpurea where the hairs on the underside of the leaf are visible.

blurbs.title: Different traits: Trapping and digesting
blurbs.text:
This is where the two really distiguish themselves, as they use similar methods of catching their prey, using nectar and hairs, they trap and digest the insects is different ways.

The Sarracenia Farnhamii, has a part of the leaf that covers the opening to prevent any rain water from collecting in it. When the pitcher opens up, it is initially empty and the inside is also lined with a similar hair that it uses the catch the bug. When the unsuspecting insect falls in it will try to crawl or fly out leading to it rubbing against the hairs lining the inside of the pitcher. Rubbing the leaves causes the plant to produce what is effectively a weak acid to digest the insect. The more the insect struggles the more acid the plant releases. The acid is produced when the hairs are stimulated and stopts shortly after. Once the plant catches more bugs, they will fall on top of the bugs that are already being digested, causing more digestive fluid to run down the pitcher and on top of the bugs below. The pitcher is also long and narrow, designed to squeeze the insects inside to cause more digestive fluid production.

The Sarracenia Purpurea, on the other hand, does not cover the top part of the pitcher deliberately to catch rain water. The pitchers themselves are also much shorter and wider, to support the weight of the water and to have more capacity to store it. When the insect falls into the pitcher, it will be trapped in the water. The walls of the pitchers are also made so the insects have trouble climbing them and to absorbe nutrients. Once the insect dies and decays, the plant will absorbe the nutrients from the water. When more insects fall in, they struggle and stir up the water with all the bits of decaying insects causing the mixture to swirl around which helps the plant absrobe it even more.

images.name: sarracenia_farnhamii
images.alt: A picture of fully grown Sarracenia Farnhamii.

plants.name: Nepenthes
plants.introduction: This is another carnivorous plant, and though it is also sometimes referred to as a pitcher plant it is a different species than Sarracenias. These plants are native to Asia and can grow in a variety of areas. These plants us a similar yet also unique way to catch their pray. This is a species I always wanted to have! I got my first Nepenthes in early 2023, it's still alive and seems to be doing well.

blurbs.text: I always wanted to make a gravity simulation, where the stellar bodies actually move around based on gravity. I've also always wanted to do something with Javascript. So, I combined the two and wrote this gravity simulation in Javascript. There are a wide variety of calculations that I had to use and it was really not as simple as I thought it would be. However, it was really fun to do and I really enjoy watching it go. Currently, is has the sun and the first 4 planets in our solar system.Github.

iterations.title: Rapid Exploring Random Trees, Fall 2021, Personal Project

blurbs.text: Rapid Exploring Random Trees is a method of exploring a terrain. The idea is that you place a target in a random location on the screen, which is not drawn, then find the closest point of the path already travelled and take a step into the direction of the random point. Continue this until you reach the goal. I learned about this a while back in a course and have now re-implemented it mostly for amusement, I just love watching it explore. It's interesting that even though it takes a random step, it still finds the goal even in really tough spots. See the code on Github.

images.name: rert
images.alt: A short animation demonstrating how the algorithm searches through some randomly generated barriers.

programming.name: Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Fall 2021, Personal Project

blurbs.text: ACO is a meta-heuristic for combinatorial optimization problems, which is a fancy way of saying routing problem. The most basic instance of a routing problem is the famous "Travelling-salesman problem" introduced by Merrill M. Flood in 1955. The basic idea is for a single salesman to visit every city with the shortest possible distance. The reason this is a combinatorial problem is because for n cities there are n! different solutions. For example, if there are 10 cities then there are 3628800 different combinations of possible routes, where one route will be the shortest. Since finding the optimal solution when n is large is not possible within a reasonable amount of time, better methods need to be developed. In ACO, the variation is that there are many ants and they make choices based on probability which is based on the distance. Meaning, a given ant can see all the cities and each city will have a probability of being visited based on the distance. So, the closest will have the highest probability and the furthest the least. Additionally, when an ant travels down a path is lays pheromones which can be seen by other ants. In which case the probability will be based on both the distance and the pheromone strength. I implemented this as a visual reprentation to see how the algorithm works based on a tutorial by Budi Santosa (2015). See the code on Github.

images.name: aco
images.alt: A short animation demonstrating how Ant Colony Optimization searches through nodes.

programming.name: Least square regression, Winter 2021, Personal Project

blurbs.text:
Least square regression simply tries to minimize the distance to all points. Ridge regression takes the error into account and tries to minimize error by giving points a weight that indicates how much this point should contribute to the model. For example, an outlier is not desirable so giving it a small weight means that it will be less likely to make the model incorrect. Additionally, once you can also use more advanced methods like nonlinear solutions. For now, I implemented the simplest version of the algorithm.

See the code on Github.

images.name: least_square_segression
images.alt: An image showing an example of least squares regression using some plotted points.

programming.name: Save Your Bacon, Fall 2019, Event Project

blurbs.text:
As part of being on the Executive Team for the Computer Science Students' Association we hosted a Game Jam. After all the event planning done by the other members and myself, we managed to make a mini game. This is a three day project that the four of us finished.

Game description: Your pig just won first prize at the county fair. The other farmers are angry that you won and start throwing rocks at your pig. The pig is defenceless against getting hit by a rock and will die immediately. Luckly, you are a skilled rock catcher so it is up to you to catch the rocks. While dodging and catching rocks, you find coins on the ground that you can use to buy protection for your pig.

See the code on Github.

images.name: saving_your_bacon
images.alt: The title screen of the game we made.

blurbs.text:
In my last year I did an honours project focusing on Quantum Computing and Quantum Information processing. This started by first looking into what a Quantum Processor is and why it is different and such a hot topic. Once I learned more about how to manage state and the underlying math behind it, I worked on writing simple quantum algorithms on IBM Q. Throughout this project I made us of technologies such as Qiskit and IBM Q Experience.

Image Retrieved from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qubit.

This is a personal project that I worked on through the summer. It's a simulation that "populates" the planets and its moons. There are calculations based on real population growth and decay, as well as a max population that can be supported on a given planet. And, of course these numbers are based on real statistics. Otherwise, where's the fun? As of now it only includes our solar system (not all pictured).

This is the project that I worked on for my Software engineering course. The five of us worked diligently to complete this game. There were many bumps in the road, but with proper communication and a lot of patience we all pulled together as a team to make this entertaining mini game.

See the code on Github.

This is a particle system that I did for an assignment and then later slightly modified. It's a rather simple program, but it was fun to make. I also like the idea of using small particles to simulate things like smoke and fire.

The particles have mass and slightly change color on every collision, which is only noticeable when the program runs for a few seconds.

See the code on Github.

Another personal project that simulates growing grass using particles. This whole program is procedurally generated. Each 'root' is made up of several blades of grass and each blade of grass is made up of several particles. The grass can grow and be mowed. I also worked on making it sway in the wind which was a challenge.

I have since learned more about optimizing code and different strategies that I could have used to accomplish similar things, but I enjoyed writing it. When I wrote this program I didn't know that this is technically a particle system, I just had the idea and wanted to try it.
